nodes.text: Computationally simple dynamic OLS (DOLS) and dynamic GLS (DGLS) estimators provide asymptotically efficient estimation and chi-squared inference for cointegrating vectors in systems with deterministic components and variables integrated of general order d, and can be applied to study long-run economic relations such as U.S. Ml demand

Method: derive two-sided triangular representation for I(1) and I(d) systems, orthogonalize errors by projecting onto leads and lags, and motivate DOLS as OLS on regression including contemporaneous levels, leads and lags of first differences and a constant and DGLS as feasible GLS using estimated serial correlation

Claim: Under general conditions (martingale difference shocks, summable lag polynomials, nonsingular spectra) the DOLS and DGLS estimators are asymptotically efficient and their Wald statistics for restrictions on cointegrating vectors have asymptotic chi-squared distributions

Method / Assumption: Represent I(d) systems as block triangular form partitioning stochastic trends by order, assume finite parameterization of certain two-sided projection polynomials when constructing feasible estimators

Result: Asymptotic theory (Theorems 1-4) â€” scaled DGLS and DOLS estimators converge to mixed normal limits with block-dependent rates, DGLS and DOLS are asymptotically equivalent for coefficients on integrated regressors, and Wald tests based on feasible GLS or robust OLS covariance are asymptotically chi-squared

Monte Carlo evidence: in a range of DGPs DOLS and DGLS eliminate bias present in static OLS, DOLS often has lower RMSE in designs with strong serial correlation and truncated approximations, but all estimators can be substantially biased in some designs and t-statistics can have heavier tails than asymptotic theory predicts

Claim: Finite-sample performance depends on short-run dynamics and degree of truncation of two-sided projection polynomials; autoregressive spectral estimators for covariance (used with DOLS) can improve finite-sample t-statistic behavior relative to kernel methods in some settings

Application method: apply DOLS, DGLS, Johansen MLE, fully-modified and spectral estimators to estimate cointegrating relation for nominal Ml with price, income and an interest rate using annual data 1900-1989 and postwar monthly data

Evidence / Result (annual full sample): Using full-sample annual data 1900-1989 DOLS (preferred) yields income elasticity about 0.97 and interest semielasticity about -0.10; 95% DOLS confidence intervals reported are (0.88,1.06) for income and (-0.127,-0.075) for interest

Evidence / Result (subsample instability): Postwar annual subsample estimates (1946-1989) are highly imprecise and vary across estimators because the postwar data are dominated by a single low-frequency trend in income and interest rates and near-zero growth in real balances, leaving only their trend line well determined (high multicollinearity)

Claim: Despite subsample instability, tests and residual analysis support stability of a long-run Ml demand relation spanning 1900-1989; prewar-estimated long-run elasticities produce postwar residuals that are consistent with cointegration, supporting Lucas' conjecture that apparent postwar sensitivity reflects lack of low-frequency variation

Limitation / Evidence: Asymptotic standard errors and chi-squared approximations can understate finite-sample uncertainty for small postwar samples; Monte Carlo coverage for nominal 95% regions can be well below 95% for some estimators and sample sizes, indicating size and precision distortions in practice

Conclusion: Use of DOLS/DGLS offers a simple, asymptotically efficient way to estimate cointegrating vectors across I(d) systems and permits inference on long-run economic relations, but practitioners should use multiple estimators, examine subsample stability, and be cautious about finite-sample precision when low-frequency variation is limited
